sections.title: Medieval India (C) The Mughal Empire
sections.content_md:
Medieval India (C) The Mughal Empire

Sources: Ain-i-Akbari, Taj Mahal, Jama Masjid and Red Fort.
Political history and administration (Babur, Akbar and Aurangzeb).

On the eve of Babur's invasion of India in 1526, India was ruled by breakaway kingdoms of the Delhi Sultanate and there was no powerful central authority. Bengal, Jaunpur, Gujarat, Malwa and Mewar had all become independent. These States were always fighting against one another with the result that a sense of insecurity and tension reigned supreme throughout the country. However, these regional kingdoms, one by one, came under the control of the Mughals.

sections.title: Sources: Ain-i-Akbari, Taj Mahal, Jama Masjid and Red Fort.
sections.content_md: This topic is covered in detail under the 'SOURCES' section.

sections.title: Political history and administration (Babur, Akbar and Aurangzeb).
sections.content_md: This topic is covered in detail under the 'MUGHAL DYNASTY' and 'ADMINISTRATIVE SYSTEM OF THE MUGHALS' sections.

sections.title: The main sources of information about the Mughals are:
Ain-i-Akbari
sections.content_md:
**Ain-i-Akbari**: It was written by **Abul Fazl**, the minister and one of the nine jewels at Akbar's court. It was a part of a large project of history writing commissioned by Akbar. It is regarded as a precious source of information about the administration and culture during the reign of Akbar.

The **Ain-i-Akbari** is divided into five books.
*   The **first book** deals with the imperial household.
*   The **second book** deals with the servants of the emperor, the military and civil services.
*   The **third book** deals with the imperial administration. It consists of the regulations for the judicial and executive departments, and the divisions of the empire.
*   The **fourth book** contains information about Hindu philosophy, science, social customs and literature.
*   The **fifth book** contains the wise sayings of Akbar. This also contains an account of the ancestry and biography of the author, Abul Fazl.

sections.title: The Taj Mahal, Agra
sections.content_md:
[Image: Taj Mahal]

It was built by **Shah Jahan** in memory of his beloved wife **Mumtaz Mahal**. It is the mausoleum of both Mumtaz Mahal and Shah Jahan. 

**Location and Design:**
*   It is built at Agra on the banks of the River Yamuna.
*   It was designed by **Ustad Isha Khan** and is made of pure white marble.
*   The main structure is constructed on a high platform. On each of the four corners of this platform there is a minaret.
*   The central dome rises to a height of 56.1 metres.
*   The interior has an octagonal chamber. The marble dome in the centre looks like an inverted lotus. The actual graves are in lower chamber, underground.

**Decoration and Architecture:**
*   The entire structure of Taj Mahal is made of marble and the walls are decorated with floral designs made of semi-precious stones. This method of decoration is called **pietra dura**.
*   The Taj Mahal brought together all the architectural forms developed by the Mughals like massive domes of marble, **pietra dura** inlay work and kiosks (**chhatris**).

**Significance:**
*   Taj Mahal was designated as a **UNESCO World Heritage site** in 1983 and was declared as one of the **Seven Wonders of the World** in 2007.

sections.title: The Jama Masjid
sections.content_md:
[Image: Jama Masjid]

**The Jama Masjid**: It was built by **Shah Jahan** and is the biggest mosque in India. Its courtyard has the capacity to accommodate thousands of people at a time. 

**Structure and Features:**
*   It is built on a lofty basement with majestic flights of steps leading to the imposing gateways on three sides of the courtyard.
*   It has three gateways, four towers and two 40m high minarets constructed of red sandstone and white marble.
*   The northern gate has 39 steps, the eastern gate has 35 steps and the southern gate has 33 steps.
*   The face of its spacious prayer-hall consists of eleven arches of which the central arch rises far above the roof level.

sections.title: The Red Fort, Delhi
sections.content_md:
[Image: Red Fort, Delhi]

**The Red Fort, Delhi**: It was built by **Shah Jahan** after he decided to shift his capital to Delhi. It is located on the banks of the Yamuna. Red sandstone and marble were used in its construction.

**Structure and Buildings:**
*   The fort has massive walls and two gateways. The Western Gateway is known as the **Lahori Gate**, which was used for the emperor's ceremonial purposes.
*   Impressive buildings in the complex include **Diwan-i-Aam** and **Diwan-i-Khas**.
*   The **Diwan-i-Khas** is the lavishly ornamented hall where the **Peacock Throne** was placed. The hall was used by the emperor to give audience to the princes of the royal family, nobles and other important dignitaries.
*   Aurangzeb later built the **Moti Masjid** in the Red Fort, made of pure marble.

**Historical Importance:**
*   The Red Fort is an important historical monument. The Prime Minister of India every year hoists the national flag from its ramparts on Independence Day (August 15).

sections.title: BABUR
sections.content_md:
[Image: Babur]

**Babur**, whose full name was **Zahir-ud-din Muhammad Babur**, was a descendant of Timur, the Mongol Ruler. He carved out a small principality for himself at Kabul.

**Invasion of India:**
*   **Daulat Khan Lodhi**, the Governor of Punjab, invited Babur to oust Ibrahim Lodhi from the throne.
*   In the **First Battle of Panipat (1526)**, Babur defeated Ibrahim Lodhi and occupied Delhi and Agra.

**Consolidation of Power:**
*   **Battle of Khanwa (1527):** Fought between Babur and Rana Sanga's forces of Mewar. Rana Sanga was defeated, which secured Babur's position in the Delhi-Agra region.
*   **Battle of Ghagra (1529):** Babur met the combined forces of the Afghans and Nusrat Shah of Bengal. Babur compelled them to retreat but could not win a decisive victory.
*   Babur died in 1530 before he could stabilise the Mughal empire.

sections.title: AKBAR
sections.content_md:
[Image: Akbar]

He was the greatest of Mughal rulers of India. He ascended the throne at thirteen years old and was guided by his tutor, **Bairam Khan**.

**Reconquest and Expansion:**
*   **Second Battle of Panipat:** The Afghans regrouped under **Hemu**, the Wazir of Adil Shah. The Mughal forces led by Bairam Khan defeated Hemu.
*   After establishing himself in Delhi and Agra, Akbar captured Malwa and Gondwana, Bengal, Gujarat, Kashmir and Kabul.
*   He ventured into the Deccan and defeated many local rulers. Ahmadnagar, Berar and Khandesh were annexed.
*   He subdued the Rajput princes, except Mewar.
*   **Battle of Haldighati (1576):** Fought between **Maharana Pratap** (ruler of Mewar) and the Mughal army led by **Raja Man Singh**. Maharana Pratap fought with courage but had to escape.

**Extent of Empire:**
*   Akbar died in 1605. His authority extended from Assam in the east to Kabul and Kandahar in the west. In the Deccan, his dominions included Ahmadnagar, Khandesh and Berar. The Kingdoms of Multan, Sindh, Gujarat, Kashmir and Bengal ceased to exist.

sections.title: Akbar's Rajput Policy:
sections.content_md:
The Rajput policy of Akbar was one of his greatest achievements. 
*   He entered into **marriage alliances** with the Rajputs. **Bhara Mal**, the ruler of Amber, married his younger daughter, **Harkha Bai** to Akbar.
*   Akbar gave complete religious freedom to his wives who followed Hinduism and also gave an honoured place to their parents and relations in the nobility.
*   This policy ended the centuries-old animosity between Muslim rulers and the Rajputs.
*   The Rajputs were made equal partners in the Mughal government, which considerably affected public policies and helped in the growth of a composite culture.

sections.title: Steps Towards Integration:
sections.content_md:
Akbar took a number of measures to promote greater understanding between the Hindus and the Muslims. Through these measures he created an atmosphere in which liberal views could grow and cultural and emotional integration of the people could develop. These measures were:
1.  **Abolition of Taxes:** Akbar abolished the poll tax or **jizyah**, which non-Muslims were required to pay. He also abolished the **pilgrim tax** on bathing at holy places like Prayag and Benaras.
2.  **Abolition of Forcible Conversion:** He abolished the practice of forcibly converting prisoners of war to Islam.
3.  **Inclusion of Hindus in Nobility:** Akbar enrolled many Hindus, mostly Rajput rajas, into the nobility. **Mansabs** (position or rank) were given to others based on their competence.
4.  **Ibadat Khana:** In 1575, Akbar built a hall called **Ibadat Khana** or the Hall of Prayer at Fatehpur Sikri. Here, he discussed religious and spiritual matters with selected theologians, mystics, and intellectuals of all religions.
5.  **Mahzar:** Akbar issued a 'Declaration' or **mahzar**, which made him the supreme or final arbiter in religious matters, replacing the power of the **ulema**.
6.  **Din-i-Illahi:** Akbar promulgated a new faith called **Din-i-Illahi**, based on the principle of oneness of God. It stressed virtues like courage, loyalty, and justice, and demanded loyalty to the Emperor. Its basic purpose was **Sulh-kul** or universal harmony, which governed all of Akbar's public policies.
7.  **Translation Department:** Akbar set up a large translation department for translating works in Sanskrit, Arabic, and Greek into Persian. Works like the **Singhasan Battisi**, the **Atharva Veda**, the **Bible**, the **Quran**, the **Mahabharata**, the **Gita** and the **Ramayana** were translated.

sections.title: SOCIAL AND EDUCATIONAL REFORMS
sections.content_md:
[Image: Akbar in the Ibadat Khana]

Akbar introduced a number of social and educational reforms:
1.  **Sati:** Akbar issued orders to the **kotwals** to check the forcible practice of **Sati**. However, women who committed Sati of their own free will were allowed to do so.
2.  **Widow Remarriage:** Akbar legalised widow remarriage.
3.  **Polygamy:** Akbar was against a man having more than one wife unless the first wife could not bear children.
4.  **Age of Marriage:** Akbar raised the age of marriage to 14 for girls and 16 for boys.
5.  **Education Syllabus:** Akbar revised the educational syllabus, laying more emphasis on moral education, mathematics, and secular subjects such as agriculture, geometry, astronomy, logic, and history.

**Educational Development under Mughals:**
*   The public works department, **Shuhra-i-am**, had a duty to build schools and colleges.
*   **Jahangir** passed a law where the assets of a rich man dying without an heir would be used by the State for educational institutions.
*   **Shah Jahan** provided scholarships to assist students.
*   **Female education** existed in some form. Girls from rich families had private tuitions, and middle-class girls could attend the same schools as boys.

sections.title: AURANGZEB
sections.content_md:
[Image: Aurangzeb]

[Image: AURANGZEB'S EMPIRE INDIA IN AD 1707]

Aurangzeb ascended the throne after a long and fierce struggle with his father and three brothers. 
*   His long reign of 50 years was devoted to wars in different parts of the country.
*   At its height, his rule extended over almost the entire subcontinent—from Kashmir in the north to river Kaveri in the south and from Kabul in the west to Chittagong in the east.
*   He reversed Akbar's policy of religious tolerance.
*   He spent the last days of his reign attempting to suppress rebellions.
*   Under Aurangzeb, the Mughal empire reached its largest extent, but also witnessed a series of political disturbances. Aurangzeb died in 1707, leaving behind an empire on the verge of collapse.

sections.title: ADMINISTRATIVE SYSTEM OF THE MUGHALS
sections.content_md: The Mughal Emperors established a centralised State based on military power. It rested on two pillars—the absolute authority of the Emperor and the strength of the army. The Mughal rulers made a conscious attempt to accommodate the different traditions prevalent in the country.

sections.title: Monarch:
sections.content_md:
Court chronicles show the belief that the power of the Mughal kings came directly from God. According to Abul Fazl, a true ruler's office was a responsible one depending on divine illumination. 
*   The Mughal Emperor was regarded as the **vice-regent of God** on earth.
*   He was the head of the executive, legislature, judiciary and the army.
*   He was the supreme commander of the armed forces; all other commanders were appointed and dismissed by him.
*   He made laws and issued administrative ordinances.
*   The royal **uzuk** (small signet ring) was affixed to **farmans** granting appointments, titles, jagirs, etc.

sections.title: Ministers:
sections.content_md:
*   **Vakil:** In the days of Babur and Humayun, the Prime Minister was known as the **vakil**, holding large powers in civil and military affairs. During Akbar's early reign, Bairam Khan was the vakil, but after his death, the office became honorary.
*   **Wazir (Diwan):** The head of the revenue department was the **wazir**, also known as **diwan** or **diwan-i-ala**. The diwan was responsible for all income and expenditure.
*   **Mir Bakhshi:** The head of the military department was called the **mir bakhshi**. He was also the head of the intelligence and information agencies of the empire.

sections.title: Judiciary:
sections.content_md: The judicial department was headed by the **qazi**. This post was sometimes combined with that of the **chief sadar**, who was responsible for all charitable and religious matters.

sections.title: Provincial Government:
sections.content_md:
Akbar organized the Provincial government. The empire was divided into twelve provinces or **subahs**, which were further subdivided into **sarkars**, and each sarkar into **parganas** or **mahals**.
*   **Subahdar:** Each Subah was headed by a governor called the **subahdar** or **sipah salar** or **nazim**. He was usually a mansabdar of high rank. His functions included maintaining law and order, enforcing imperial decrees, administering criminal justice, and ensuring smooth revenue collection.
*   **Provincial Diwan:** He was in charge of the revenue administration of the province.
*   **Other officials:** Important officials in the province included the **faujdar, kotwal, bakhshi, sadr qazi** and **muhtasib**.
*   Officials of the provinces, sarkars and parganas were appointed by the Centre, making these divisions directly responsible to the central government.

sections.title: Mansabdari System:
sections.content_md:
The **mansabdari system**, introduced by Akbar, was a unique feature of Mughal administration. 
*   Under this system, every officer was assigned a rank (**mansab**).
*   The term **mansabdar** refers to an individual who holds a mansab (a position or rank). The mansabdars formed the ruling group in the empire.
*   It was a grading system used by the Mughals to fix rank, salary and military responsibilities. The lowest rank was 10, and the highest was 5000 for nobles.

**Zat and Sawar Ranks:**
*   Ranks were divided into two: **zat** and **sawar**.
*   **Zat** fixed the personal status of a person and the salary due to him. A higher zat meant a more prestigious position and larger salary.
*   **Sawar** rank indicated the number of cavalrymen a mansabdar was required to maintain. For every ten cavalrymen, the mansabdar had to maintain twenty horses.

**Jagirs and Later Changes:**
*   Mansabdars received their salaries as revenue assignments called **jagirs**. Most mansabdars did not reside in or administer their jagirs; they only had rights to the revenue, which was collected by their servants.
*   **Jahangir** reduced the average rate of zat salary.
*   **Shah Jahan** reduced the number of sawars a noble was required to maintain, to about one-third or one-fourth of his sawar rank.
*   During **Aurangzeb's** reign, a huge increase in the number of mansabdars created a shortage in the number of jagirs.

sections.title: Land Revenue System:
sections.content_md: A uniform system of measurement was established for calculating the land tax. **Todar Mal** drew up schemes for effective tax collection. This system enriched the state treasury. The state also gave loans to poor farmers, which ushered in progress in agriculture, trade and industry.

sections.title: TIMELINE
sections.content_md:
*   **1530** Accession of Humayun.
*   **1540** End of the Mughal empire; Battle of Kannauj; Establishment of the Suri empire by Sher Shah Suri.
*   **1545** Death of Sher Shah Suri.
*   **1555** End of the Suri empire; Re-establishment of the Mughal empire.
*   **1556** Death of Humayun; Accession of Akbar; Second Battle of Panipat.
*   **1605** Death of Akbar; Accession of Jahangir.
*   **1627** Death of Jahangir; Birth of Shivaji.
*   **1628** Accession of Shah Jahan.
*   **1658** Accession of Aurangzeb.
*   **1675** Execution of Guru Tegh Bahadur by Aurangzeb.
*   **1707** Death of Aurangzeb; Accession of Bahadur Shah I.
*   **1837** Accession of Bahadur Shah Zafar.
*   **1858** End of the Mughal dynasty; Bahadur Shah Zafar exiled to Myanmar.
